posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14553739
>Meh. They still spoke albanian as late as 2-3 generations ago.
Oh for sure, however Arvanitika, despite being related to Tosk Albanian, is extremely divergent and Hellenized which is only natural owing to the centuries spent separated from Albania proper.
I say this as someone who's patrilineal line is Arvanite, and who's great-grandfather spoke it.
>>14553989
>Basically Greece was populated by Albanians
It really wasn't the entirety. It's basically Western Roumeli, parts of the Northern Peloponnese, and a few Aegean Islands near those parts of the mainland.
>And from the Greek perspective, they already completely lost any connection to their hellenic pagan past and shunned it even, instead bought fully into the Christianity thing and made the Byzantine Empire into a Christian State. They called themselves Romans and aggressively assimilated many local ethnicities into Greek Orthodox.
This oversimplifies and blends periods of time. Prior to the extinction of Hellenic Paganism, Hellenes were still associated with being pagan leading to the preference to refer to oneself as Christian or Roman (Rhomaoi). However, almost immediately after Hellenic paganism went extinct in the 9th Century, we see as early as the 10th Century during the Macedonian Renaissance, a reclamation of the Hellenic identity, which would be furthered during the Palaeologan Renaissance some centuries later. Point being, the Hellenic identity was never entirely forgotten, just that the Christian identity was emphasised. As for Arvanites, yes being Orthodox, they were subject to the Rum Millet, but had already felt kinship with their fellow Orthodox prior to this, and would continue this into the revolution. The only reason they gradually abandoned their language was because their aims at incorporating other Christian Albanians in Albanian proper into Greece during the revolution failed, and they wanted to distance themselves from those still under Ottoman rule.

1 Thessalonians details Paul's beliefs that the Thessalonian church shouldn't despair about those who have died before the return of Jesus, since they will reunite with the dead believers and with Jesus in the air, which would happen within the lifetimes of the people he was directly sending the letter to.

2 Peter wasn't written by Peter, it was a forged letter written by someone pretending to be. Neither of the Petrine epistles were written by Peter, they were written by two different people both pretending to be Peter in order to give greater authority to their personal beliefs. Peter was likely illiterate.

All sermons Jesus gives on the apocalypse are flanked with speech on how the signs that the apocalypse was coming were already underway. With each subsequent gospel, the immanence of the apocalypse is toned down in favor of adding lines about how the apocalypse isn't actually immanent. The first group are likely authentic, since they meet the criterion of embarrassment and are perfectly in line with the kingdom of God ideology, one which implied the world would end soon and the dead would soon be raised. The second don't meet that criterion, and are more likely to have been added at a later date in order to neutralize the importance of the first. The first group may be embarrassing things to say, but the author has to include them since Jesus likely actually said them. The second group were inserted into the tradition (or by the writer themself) at a later date, in order to tone down the embarrassing apocalypticism.

But even within the kingdom of God ideology itself, Jesus isn't claiming exact knowledge when the son of man would come to end the world. He was saying it'd happen within the lifetimes of his direct audience, but no one knows the exact hour, therefore everyone must "keep watch" since the end will come at an unexpected hour (for them.) He's not saying it's gonna happen in 2000 years.

The point of crucifying someone is to leave them on the cross, a warning to the population not to rebel during their most nationalistic festival of the year. Pilate didn't care about Jewish sensitivities and was constantly offending them, he would eventually get fired for massacring a bunch of Samaritans. It doesn't make sense for him to remove Jesus' body, since the point of crucifying three Jews right outside of Jerusalem for everyone to see during their holiest time of the year was to send the message that he didn't care about their sensitivities, and was holding a "zero tolerance" policy for dissent during Passover. Jesus was likely left on the cross to rot, like virtually everyone else who was crucified.

There never was a tomb nor a Joseph of Arimathea, both of those had to be invented later to explain how Jesus could've been raised without anyone seeing him. But, as the "risen Jesus" of the gospels himself implies (and as the angels themselves state,) belief in the resurrection would first start with Peter back in Galilee, not in Jerusalem. Since the Jews didn't believe someone could exist without their body, the resurrection was always assumed to be a bodily one.

The proper and intended subject of the Lord's words are only His coronation, the final judgement and the consummation of the world.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Somewhat /pol/ related thread, but still fair game for /his/ posters.

Being 40 years removed from the initial wave of support engendered by the Reagan/Thatcher revolution that brought the ideas of austerity (admittedly offset by the military build-up spending during the 80s), global free trade, and deregulation, I'd like to gauge what the average anon's verdict is as regards to achieving its stated goals. The whole purpose of these policies initially was to allow for a more business friendly environment such that the domestic firms that had stagnated and were losing ground to foreign competitors during the 1970s could be given the incentive and the capital resources to invest in new plant, equipment, and R&D. However, many in hindsight would argue that the deregulation of financial markets, particularly the repeal of Glass-Steagall in the United States, and the opening up of countries to greater foreign investment and exchange of commodities and labor (via arrangements and institutions such as GATT, NAFTA, and the WTO, as well as changes in various countries' immigration laws) only served to sever the connection that kept capital at home serving the nation and instead gave corporations free reign to seek higher dividends through the outsourcing of manufacturing operations to those areas with the lowest labor costs (i.e Southeast Asia and Mexico). This, of course, has meant the loss of many skilled jobs and a net reduction of human capital in those countries whose firms have exported their labor costs overseas, while a net inflow of foreign investment capital has meant a reduced reliance on domestic savings for start-up and expanding businesses.

On net balance, then, it seems that the neoliberal agenda has produced good and bad. Many see it as the source of the West's evils (i.e. demographic replacement through lax immigration, concentration of wealth in multinational corporations, etc.) while others see it as the source of our contemporary success. What say you?

>>14555557
I think this gets to the heart of the issue. Neoliberal theorists like Friedman, Hayek, and others believed that the productive energies that had driven U.S. economic growth from the early 19th to the mid 20th century were being stymied by the disincentives of red-tape and legally imposed barriers to entry that prevented the innovation process resulting from competitive capitalism from taking place. Simply remove the bureaucratic bloat, introduce competitive pressures, and, boom, the economy would rebound like never before.

The issue is that rather than using those tax credits and easier legal climate to invest in new plant and equipment, most U.S. firms saw that the profit margin could be maximized in the short term by outsourcing most of their manufacturing operations altogether.

This is to say nothing of the financial deregulation, which has been disastrous to say the least. The S&L crisis should have taught lawmakers the dangers of lax regulatory policy combined with the incentives of a 'bail-out' guarantee (i.e. FSLIC). Instead, we got the repeal of Glass-Steagall, the Community Reinvestment Act, and easy credit courtesy of the Federal Reserve. Obviously, the 2008 financial crisis and all subsequent macro phenomena have a far more complicated history in terms of causation, but the groundwork was undeniably laid by the Reagan and Clinton era rollback of regulation of financial markets.

The only real sectors of the American economy that benefited directly from neoliberal policies were Silicon Valley, real estate, and healthcare. Fortune 500 companies that have emerged from that period onward are merely those who have optimized their business structure to take advantage of easily-sourced cheap labour, abundant foreign capital, and improved logistics from integrating computer technology into their daily operations.

Rather than resulting in a new wave of general productivity, deregulation instead created the ideal environment for rent-seeking.

>>14555601
GDP is only a measure of what's exchanged at POS. It says nothing about the concentration or distribution of wealth in a society, or how ownership of that wealth reflects in decision-making power. "Economic freedom" in the sense of an individual starting his or her own business with his or her own resources, or else relying on resources available from local sources, is dead as disco. The central banks and the corporate financial institutions have an effective monopoly on credit; they decide which enterprises get off the ground and which do not. They lay out the terms of repayment and they own most of the assets, not the proprietor or management.

Economic freedom is proportional to ownership of capital goods; the more one owns, the more free one is to spend one's time, resources, or energies on other pursuits. It is this opportunity for alternative choice that constitutes real freedom, and not the mere fact that "market relationships" exist between two transacting parties.

Hence, a society in which private ownership is widely distributed and in which material progress is driven by productive competition is the ideal scenario. Unfortunately, however, firms operating under the principle of profit maximization have historically sought to undermine the forces of competition and consolidate their control over a given market. Hence why regulation and anti-trust laws exist. The state has a necessary role in maintaining the safety and security of its citizens and enforcing standards of fairness and honesty among corporations.

Deregulation has overall proven to be a mixed bag, with certain industries, such as airlines, benefiting, but with others proving to be disastrous (i.e. the financial markets). Ironically, most public sector unions avoided clamp down on organized labor and ended up retaining the most unproductive and useless segment of the population (public school teachers, office workers, bullshitters, etc.)

I think you're painting with too broad a brush. Undoubtedly, there were and are "capitalists" in the Marxian sense of the word; individuals who prioritize profit maximizing above all else, and will lobby for whatever benefits they can get from government. But there were also folks like Reagan and Limbaugh who, though not literate in the technical details of economic policy, no doubt believed that a scaling back of big government and the allowance of a greater degree of freedom for private institutions was in the best interest of the whole society. The American experiment in government originates in suspicion towards centralized power and the privilege that innevitably results from its use.

I think that the first generation of neoliberal politicians (Reagan/Thatcher era) simply miscalculated the long-run effects that their reforms would have when operating in tandem (i.e. deindustrialization, financial rent-seeking and its the associated bubbles, ballooning higher education costs due to inordinate demand and credentialism in the job market, tech oligopolies, and the influx of cheap labor via lax immigration).

Its the second and third generation suits, such as the Clinton and Bush administrations and the "Atari Democrats", along with lobbying entities that wanted to open up the USA to the influence of foreign investment capital, that are really to blame. They knew exactly what they were doing. But so long as you're a part of the globally minded, socially mobile, technocratic elite, I guess it doesn't matter where you spend your money or what a given country's demographics look like. Money spends just as well either way.

>>14555794
We are not in a good position to assess the probability of whether God has morally sufficient reasons for the evils that occur. As finite persons, we are limited in time, space, intelligence, and insight. But the transcendent and sovereign God sees the end from the beginning and providentially orders history so that His purposes are ultimately achieved through human free decisions. In order to achieve His ends, God may have to put up with certain evils along the way. Evils which appear pointless to us within our limited framework may be seen to have been justly permitted within God’s wider framework. To borrow an illustration from a developing field of science, Chaos Theory, scientists have discovered that certain macroscopic systems, for example, weather systems or insect populations, are extraordinarily sensitive to the tiniest perturbations. A butterfly fluttering on a branch in West Africa may set in motion forces which would eventually issue in a hurricane over the Atlantic Ocean. Yet it is impossible in principle for anyone observing that butterfly palpitating on a branch to predict such an outcome. The brutal murder of an innocent man or a child’s dying of leukemia could produce a sort of ripple effect through history such that God’s morally sufficient reason for permitting it might not emerge until centuries later and perhaps in another land. When you think of God’s providence over the whole of history, I think you can see how hopeless it is for limited observers to speculate on the probability that God could have a morally sufficient reason for permitting a certain evil. We’re just not in a good position to assess such probabilities.

>>14556029
1. The Argument from Motion: Our senses can perceive motion by seeing that things act on one another. Whatever moves is moved by something else. Consequently, there must be a First Mover that creates this chain reaction of motions. This is God. God sets all things in motion and gives them their potential.
2. The Argument from Efficient Cause: Because nothing can cause itself, everything must have a cause or something that creates an effect on another thing. Without a first cause, there would be no others. Therefore, the First Cause is God.
3. The Argument from Necessary Being: Because objects in the world come into existence and pass out of it, it is possible for those objects to exist or not exist at any particular time. However, nothing can come from nothing. This means something must exist at all times. This is God.
4. The Argument from Gradation: There are different degrees of goodness in different things. Following the “Great Chain of Being,” which states there is a gradual increase in complexity, created objects move from unformed inorganic matter to biologically complex organisms. Therefore, there must be a being of the highest form of good. This perfect being is God.
5. The Argument from Design: All things have an order or arrangement that leads them to a particular goal. Because the order of the universe cannot be the result of chance, design and purpose must be at work. This implies divine intelligence on the part of the designer. This is God.

>>14553430
I thought up a small argument against image veneration myself.

1. One of their claims is that Christ's incarnation, God taking upon himself an image, means that we can show veneration to God through man-made images. But we can only show veneration through a man-made image, not worship. But Christ can be worshiped through his actual physical presence, if he were literally present. So there isn't a direct analogy between Christ's body and a statue or painting. They're necessarily in different categories.

2. If only veneration can be shown to a man-made image of Christ, this means that the only way to worship Christ is without a man-made image. You can never worship him through it or you would be committing idolatry. So the use of images requires you to show less honor to Christ than he is actually due.

Interestingly, many early Christian apologists appealed to the aniconism of the ancients in justifying Christianity. Heraclitus rejected idols as well, and Rome was well-known to have rejected all idols for the first century of its existence. It is like Romans 1 teaches, people exchange God for creation.

Numa Pompilius:
> His opinion, also, of images is very agreeable to the doctrine of Pythagoras; who conceived of the first principle of being as transcending sense and passion, invisible and incorrupt, and only to be apprehended by abstract intelligence. So Numa forbade the Romans to represent God in the form of man or beast, nor was there any painted or graven image of a deity admitted amongst them for the space of the first hundred and seventy years, all which time their temples and chapels were kept free and pure from images; to such baser objects they deemed it impious to liken the highest, and all access to God impossible, except by the pure act of the intellect.

>>14553604
Panagia may also refer to a prosphoron (Ἄρτος της Παναγίας, Ártos tēs Panagías, "Bread of the All-Holy") which is solemnly blessed in honor of the Theotokos during the Divine Liturgy (see Prosphora for details). From this loaf, a large triangle in honour of the Theotokos is cut and placed on the diskos (paten) during the Liturgy of Preparation. The remainder of the loaf is blessed over the Holy Table (altar) during the hymn Axion Estin, just before the blessing of the antidoron. The priest makes the Sign of the Cross with the Panagia over the Sacred Mysteries (consecrated Body and Blood of Christ) as he says, "Great is the name of the Holy Trinity."
https://www.liquisearch.com/panagia/blessed_bread

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14554057
>it would eventually collapse the second we left
Americans withdrew from combat operations starting in 1970. The South Vietnamese took over most of the actual fighting and were able to suppress guerrilla attacks fairly effectively. They were also able to fend off conventional campaigns by the North Vietnamese army with the help of American air support. After the complete withdrawal of American military forces in 1973, the South Vietnamese survived for two more years, defeating more North Vietnamese invasions before the final fall in 1975. Even in 1975 the South Vietnamese army was still putting up serious resistance to the North, it was only when it became apparent that America was not going to honor the Paris Peace Accords and continue to support them that morale collapsed.

South Vietnam was perfectly capable of defending itself against North Vietnam. What it was not able to do was defend against North Vietnam armed and supplied by Russia and China when its own superpower ally decided to leave it swinging in the wind.

>Britain
Foreign policy post-Napoleonic/Crimean War was to try their best to stay the fuck out of major wars, focus on expanding trade and making economic wins. Their strength is naval, not land forces. The British were also fence-sitters, preferring to let the Union and Confederates bleed each other. If the Confederates had won a decisive victory (like, destroy a whole army, conquer a whole state, or take Washington DC), then the Brits might have sided with the Confederates or at least recognized them. But the Confederates never won such an decisive strategic victory and the British weren't going to bleed themselves dry for a lost cause and unpopular slave holders.
>France

posts.com:
OP
Just at a basic level of intuition, have you never had the experience of something feeling true and false at the same time?
Like when you see through an optical illusion? Or when your foot falls asleep and it's your foot but not your foot?
With illusions we might try to explain away the paradoxical sensation scientifically but nevertheless it still feels paradoxical. I think you are hoping that there is some trick to the Trinity that lets you make sense of the paradoxical feeling.

But suppose there are paradoxes that are paradoxical feeling and can't be explained away. These paradoxes are just brute facts. There is nothing more to say about them or explain.

Also, there is an air of circularity
>How is it possible to be separate but the same at the same time?

People who reject the Trinity often proceed through this type of argument,
1) If doctrine of the Trinity is true, then it is not contradictory
2) The doctrine of the Trinity is contradictory.
3) Hence, the law of non-contradiction entails that the Trinity is false.
How could we ever hope to persuade you if you are starting from a point of reference where the law of non-contradiction applies to all propositions?

The point here is two fold. First, the Trinity IS paradoxical and accordingly FEELS paradoxical and thus the intuition that you cannot understand it isn't necessarily ironclad evidence that it is false. Second, a logical argument against the Trinity that assumes the law of non-contradiction isn't as ironclad of argument as you might think because it is circular.

Instead, I'd suggest you appraise your broader metaphysical, epistemic, and theological commitments as a whole to see if the doctrine of the Trinity fits into your holistic view of things.

>Modalism is believing that God has one essence and one person which manifests itself in different modes at different times ("water, ice and vapour").

>>14553710
Although the universal and particular exist in every genus, nevertheless, in a certain special way, the individual belongs to the genus of substance. For substance is individualized by itself; whereas the accidents are individualized by the subject, which is the substance; since this particular whiteness is called "this," because it exists in this particular subject. And so it is reasonable that the individuals of the genus substance should have a special name of their own; for they are called "hypostases," or first substances.

Further still, in a more special and perfect way, the particular and the individual are found in the rational substances which have dominion over their own actions; and which are not only made to act, like others; but which can act of themselves; for actions belong to singulars. Therefore also the individuals of the rational nature have a special name even among other substances; and this name is "person."

Thus the term "individual substance" is placed in the definition of person, as signifying the singular in the genus of substance; and the term "rational nature" is added, as signifying the singular in rational substances.

(Summa Theologica, q.29)

8. Some persons, however, find a difficulty in this faith; when they hear that the Father is God, and the Son God, and the Holy Spirit God, and yet that this Trinity is not three Gods, but one God; and they ask how they are to understand this: especially when it is said that the Trinity works indivisibly in everything that God works, and yet that a certain voice of the Father spoke, which is not the voice of the Son; and that none except the Son was born in the flesh, and suffered, and rose again, and ascended into heaven; and that none except the Holy Spirit came in the form of a dove. They wish to understand how the Trinity uttered that voice which was only of the Father; and how the same Trinity created that flesh in which the Son only was born of the Virgin; and how the very same Trinity itself wrought that form of a dove, in which the Holy Spirit only appeared. Yet, otherwise, the Trinity does not work indivisibly, but the Father does some things, the Son other things, and the Holy Spirit yet others: or else, if they do some things together, some severally, then the Trinity is not indivisible. It is a difficulty, too, to them, in what manner the Holy Spirit is in the Trinity, whom neither the Father nor the Son, nor both, have begotten, although He is the Spirit both of the Father and of the Son. Since, then, men weary us with asking such questions, let us unfold to them, as we are able, whatever wisdom God's gift has bestowed upon our weakness on this subject; neither let us go on our way with consuming envy. Should we say that we are not accustomed to think about such things, it would not be true; yet if we acknowledge that such subjects commonly dwell in our thoughts, carried away as we are by the love of investigating the truth, then they require of us, by the law of charity, to make known to them what we have herein been able to find out.

(St. Augustine, De Trinitate, Book I, Chapter 5)

"While Augustine was working on his book On the Trinity, he was walking by the seaside one day, meditating on the difficult problem of how God could be three Persons at once. He came upon a little child. The child had dug a little hole in the sand, and with a small spoon or seashell was scooping water from the sea into the small hole. Augustine watched him for a while and finally asked the child what he was doing. The child answered that he would scoop all the water from the sea and pour it into the little hole in the sand. ‘What?’ Augustine said. ‘That is impossible. posts.com: The answer to your question is naval power. Even while Japan maintained its sea-ban policy, the archipelagic geography of the country still supported domestic fishing and trade fleets. In 1832, a 150-ton Japanese rice transport blew off course, losing its mast and rudder, and was seaworthy enough to drift for 14 months to Washington State with three survivors. The Dutch outpost on Dejima provided a trickle of Western learning, and in the 1850s became a full-blown naval institute with Dutch training officers and a donated steamship. They were quicky replaced by the Royal Navy, who were happy to see another threat to Russian expansion in Asia. This begat a contest between Britain, Germany, and France to win over the Meiji government with gifts of arms and engineering expertise. By the 1870s British-built Japanese ships were menacing Taiwan and Korea. These conflicts, culminating in the Treaty of Shimonoseki in 1895, awarded Japan cash indemnities that they used to buy more ships. By 1905 Japan had amassed the sixth-largest navy in the world. Japanese shipyards acheived technical parity around WWI, relieving them of any reliance on Western goodwill, and the rest is history.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14543404
Despite the huge size of the complex most residents had no idea what was going on. In many ways they had it better than a lot of Poles in other parts of Poland. The huge number of SS personnel and other German settlers required servants and many residents found employment and protection that way. My grandmother was a teenage girl during the war and she became a maid for a family of German settlers who actually treated her well, giving her all sorts of luxury items for her service. On the flipside a portion of the population was expelled to make space for the camp and some residents became more aware or less complicit than others and were smuggling medicine and food inside the camp or helping forced laborers escape.
Generally speaking the public was unaware of what was going on inside the camp until the later stages of the war. From 1942 to 1944 a lot of escapees wrote reports that eventually made their way to the Home Army, then the Polish government in exile, then the Allied governments and finally the press. This increased awareness eventually led Jewish communities in the US and Britain to advocate for bombing campaigns against the camp's railway infrastructure but the only raid that actually took place was against IG Farben works at the Monowitz subcamp

>>14543443
Auschwitz II originally started off as a POW camp, but it's purpose quickly changed
It wasn't a pure extermination camp in a sense that everyone who ended up at Birkenau would be gassed, but rather it served as both a giant distribution centre for the Reich's slave labor system as well as an extermination place for those who were deemed too useless to be a slave laborer. Many people (mainly Poles) were in Birkenau only for transit purposes. Out of those who remained not all of them were killed outright as the Auschwitz complex had its own labor requirements. Inmates were used to expand the camp, guard each other, sort through people's personal belongings or for work in various subcamps. So in this sense it wasn't a pure extermination camp, but industrial killing was without a shadow of a doubt one of Birkenau's functions

>>14551050
Wooden doors can be made gas tight if constructed sturdily enough, and with a sealing material between the slats, which these doors were. The preassure differences between the inside of the room and the outside of the room would have been equal; the only gas transfer the doors would have needed to counter was from diffusion. They did not need to be pressure-sealed hatches like what you see on submarines, for example.

Keep in mind also that poison gas killes based on its concentration. Even the presence of small leaks would not have hampered operation of the gas chamber. Consider how with carbon monoxide poisoning, some people in the building can die while others in a nearby room remain unharmed.

>The cog was a boat design which is believed to have evolved from (or at least have been influenced by) the longship and was in wide use by the 12th century. It too used the clinker method of construction. Ships began to be built with straight stem posts and the rudder was fixed to the stern post which made a boat easier to steer. To make ships faster, more masts and sails were fitted.

The Hanseatic League was an alliance of trading guilds that established and maintained a trade monopoly over the Baltic Sea and to a certain extent the North Sea in the Late Middle Ages, starting in the 13th century. Protection for the league was given in England in 1157. Warehouses belonging to the league were set up in eight English ports and one Scottish port. By the 16th century the league imploded and there was a rise of Dutch and English merchants.

In the 14th and 15th centuries, seamen's guilds were formed in Bristol, King's Lynn, Grimsby, Hull, York and Newcastle.

Age of Exploration
From the early 15th century, continuing into the 17th century, English ships travelled around the world searching for new trading partners and establishing new trading routes. In the process new peoples were encountered and lands were mapped that were previously unknown to the English. Bristol ships were venturing into the Atlantic Ocean in 1480/1 and may have reached Newfoundland.
>During the 17th century ship experienced significant change. During the early part of the 17th century, English shipbuilders developed sturdy, well masted and defensible ships, that because of the way they were rigged, required a significant crew to man.

>>14550599
England's first known navy was established by Alfred the Great which, despite inflicting a significant defeat on the Vikings in the Wantsum Channel, Kent, fell into disuse. It was revived by Athelstan and had 400 ships in 937. When the Norman invasion was imminent, King Harold had trusted his navy to prevent William the Conqueror's fleet from crossing the Channel. However, not long before the invasion, the fleet was damaged in a storm, driven into harbour and the Normans were able to cross unopposed.

The Norman kings created a naval force in 1155, or adapted a force that already existed, with ships provided by the Cinque Ports. The English Navy began to develop during the 12th and 13th centuries, King John having a fleet of 500 sails. In the mid 14th century Edward III's navy had 712 ships. There then followed a period of decline.

Again, the base of English Naval Supremacy was formed in the viking age, the added Carracks in the 15th century does not detract from the original roots of their naval power

Going back to the start: The Roman Empire had similar conflict resolution mechanisms enabling pan-European and some pan-Asiatic trade. Most of this was done through marine shipping and waterways. The breakdown of such systems in the west permitted Ottomans increased, and more aggressive, expansion of such trade in the east (usually overland but not entirely) making them wealthy. Many were still farmers, herdsmen, fishermen, etc but a larger middle class developed and remained until discovery of the new world. The Ottomans were consistently wealthy until ~1600. Which, not coincidentally, was around the same time the first English colony at Jamestown, Virginia was planned and setup in 1607. By this point all Western powers had navies whereas the Ottomans and Russians didn't. Industrial development resulting from this would prove to be hugely consequential over the next 400 years.

Democrats needed to win local elections in the North in the later 1800s so they tapped into immigrants via political machines. During the same period, Jim Crow shit led many blacks to move north to the cities. So they became part of that city machine politics system. Since it was regional, southerners voted for their local Democrats while northerners for theirs. People back then didn't have mass media so it was a lot harder for geographically distant people to get mad over ideological purity. Meaning a racist white southerner and a black southerner-that-moved-north would just be on the same team during this period because of regional politics differences. Anyway, this is how the Democratic coalition ended up looking like it did by FDR's time. The Republicans on the other hand, who were much more ideologically-minded (anti-slavery and anti-polygamy) accomplished those ideological goals by the late 1800s, so they needed new ones. At first it was crap like gold vs. silver standard, but what happened once the other Roosevelt (Teddy) came on the scene was a push for progressivist politics. During the same time, other Republicans like Coolidge wanted more financial conservative practices. Think about it this way: during a time when the only people who had the luxury to give a shit about economic ideology were rich whites in the North, there was space for both sides in the same party, both the welfare-ish and the Wall Street Republican direction. So the Repubs were both because of this, and the Democrats were also both because of their strange coalition, which due to regional needs influenced corresponding ideology). Both parties had left and right wings during the early 20th century because of this. Since the usefulness of cities and immigrants grew for Democrats, and the Southerners didn't want to stick around with that anymore as the Dems' ideology shifted to suit their main base, right-wingers fought to take over the GOP from moderates, for strategic victory

>The deportation of the Chechens and Ingush (Chechen: Дóхaдap, Maхкaх дaхap,[4][5][6][7] Ingush: Meхкaх дaхap), or Ardakhar Genocide (Chechen: Apдaхap Maхкaх), and also known as Operation Lentil (Russian: Чeчeвицa, romanized: Chechevitsa; Chechen: нoхчий a, гӀaлгӀaй a мaхкaхбaхap, romanized: noxçiy a ġalġay a maxkaxbaxar), was the Soviet forced transfer of the whole of the Vainakh (Chechen and Ingush) populations of the North Caucasus to Central Asia on February 23, 1944, during World War II. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14553524
The issue of the Achaemenid Empire's strength in the face of Alexander's invasion has always remained a debate. The reigning ruler was Darius III, who was already middle aged, and famous as a soldier and fighter but had no actual experience ruling, leading, or administrating the empire. The last competent Achaemenid ruler was his cousin and predecessor, Atarxerxes III, who was assassinated by Bagos. And the empire had been busy putting down more rebellions in the eastern satrapies and in the ongoing upheaval that lasted nearly 60+ years with the instability of Egypt.

The only thing we know for certain is the quality of early Persian cataphracts that were the nucleus of the late Achaemenid period army and their cavalry in general. Other than that, incompetent advisors, corrupt court officials, and an inexperienced king didn't really put the footing there to call the Achaemenids still "strong" in the face of a major external threat. But again, the Persian and Mede calvary did match the Greek/Macedonians equally and Alexander nearly died a few times in battle against them.

>>14553613
Memnon of Rhodes defeated Parmenion at Magnesia in 336 with the Satrapal army. He came very close to defeating Alexander during the Siege of Halicarnus (it was a very closely fought siege). Spitamenes defeated Coenus and his small force during the Sogdia/Bactria Campaign. Whether through natives troops or mercenaries, the Achaemenid Empire was capable of defeating the Macedonians, in some form at least. The empire wasn't quite as decrepit and things are made out to be.
I'm not sure how many generals could have won Guagamela. It's a bit more complex than the typical "win the flank cavalry battle and rear charge the enemy (unless your Antiochus III)" that so typical of Macedonian generalship. Hell, even Issus decisive flanking blow was done through a combination of infantry and cavalry. And this before we get into operations and grand strategy. There really is a tendency to just assume that anyone could have done it in Alexander's position, but I'm not so sure.
